Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Large: Assuring the Safety, Security and Reliability of Medical Device Cyber Physical Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to establish a new development paradigm that enables the effective design, implementation, and certification of medical device cyber-physical systems. The approach is to pursue the following research directions: 1) to support medical device interconnectivity and interoperability with network-enabled control; 2) to apply coordination between medical devices to support emerging clinical scenarios; 3) to ?close the loop? and enable feedback about the condition of the patient to the devices delivering therapy; and 4) to assure safety and effectiveness of interoperating medical devices.
The intellectual merits of the project are 1) foundations for rigorous development, which include formalization of clinical scenarios, operational procedures, and architectures of medical device systems, as well as patient and caregiver modeling; 2) high-confidence software development for medical device systems that includes the safe and effective composition of clinical scenarios and devices into a dynamically assembled system; 3) validation and certification of medical device cyber-physical systems; and 4) education of the next-generation of medical device system developers who must be literate in both computational and physical aspects of devices.
The broader impacts of the project will be achieved in three ways. Novel design methods and certification techniques will significantly improve patient safety. The introduction of closed-loop scenarios into clinical practice will reduce the burden that caregivers are currently facing and will have the potential of reducing the overall costs of health care. Finally, the educational efforts and outreach activities will increase awareness of careers in the area of medical device systems and help attract women and under-represented minorities to the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A typical MCPS consists of multiple interconnected medical devices involved in the diagnosis and treatment of a patient.  Pooling together data from multiple physiological sensors and electronic medical records in real time allows engineers to develop more informative sensor fusion, decision support, and closed-loop control algorithms.  These algorithms use models of patient physiology to enable more powerful diagnostics, smarter alarms, safety interlocks and, ultimately, sufficient situational awareness to "close the loop" and perform routine treatment procedures automatically.

At the same time, these opportunities also raise new challenges in design and implementation of MCPS.  Data from disparate sources need to be timely delivered and properly interpreted by the algorithms, in order to guarantee that patient safety is not compromised.  High degree of connectivity between medical devices and their environment may create new vulnerabilities to cyber-attacks that can directly harm the patient.  Addressing these safety and security challenges required interdisciplinary research with close collaboration between clinicians and engineers.

Major research outcomes of the project fall into the following three categories:

- Model-based design and verification techniques for MCPS.  The first step in guaranteeing the safety of MCPS is to ensure that every device, as well as the system overall, is operating according to its requirements.  Tools and techniques developed in this line of research led to the development of a Generic Infusion Pump (GIP), an open-source set of design artifacts for control software of an infusion pump and prototype implementations of this software on commercial infusion pump platforms.  This set of artifacts can be used in case studies for future design and verification projects in academia, as well as provide guidance to medical device industry on building and documenting high-assurance medical devices.  The Generic Infusion Pump project has been performed in close contact with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, which referred to GIP artifacts in the FDA Infusion Pump Improvement Initiative.

- Platform support for medical device interoperability.  MCPS instances are assembled on demand at patient bedside from available devices to execute a clinical scenario determined by the patient condition.  We developed special-purpose middleware that ensures correct coordination of medical devices according to the specification of a clinical scenario.  Tools were developed in close collaboration with clinicians at the Massachusetts General Hospital and the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, and have been evaluated in a number of clinical studies. 

- Smart alarm and decision support MCPS applications.  We used the infrastructure for integrating flows of physiological data, described above, to design data-driven algorithms to design algorithms that alert clinicians to potentially dangerous changes in the patient condition.  The main challenge addressed by our research is to minimize the effects physiological variability between different patients, ensuring that each patient gets the best possible quality of monitoring.  Several important clinical scenarios were considered.  For example, prediction of imminent critical shunts in infants' lungs, when on of the lungs stops supplying oxygen and can quickly cause damage to brain and other organs.  Another example is a non-invasive meal detector.  Accurate detection of meals is a critical part of the control system in artificial pancreas, a new type of device that automatically injects doses of insulin to keep blood glucose concentration in diabetic patients within set bounds, preventing both hypo- and hyperglycemia.  Results have been evaluated using anonymized data from actual patients at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania and Children's Hospital of Philadelphia, and demonstrated effectiveness of the developed techniques.

Findings from the project are used in preparing CPS-aware workforce.  The course CIS 441, "Embedded Software for Life-Critical Applications," is taught annually at the University of Pennsylvania, where students learn model-based design techniques for safety assurance, using medical device examples as course projects.
